Alumnus shortlisted for top sci-fi writing prize https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2015-archive-1/february/alumnus-shortlisted-for-top-sci-fi-writing-prize Latest novel by Geology graduate Rod Duncan is in the running for the Philip K Dick Award An alumnus and former staff member at the University is on the shortlist for one of world's most prestigious sci-fi writing prizes, the Philip K Dick Award.

The only British author on the shortlist, he has been nominated for his book The Bullet Catcher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Daughter, part one of a series of at least three books which will form \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Fall of the Gas-lit Empire\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. It is set in a Victorianesque version of Leicester and Lincolnshire and events happen in the aftermath of a Luddite revolution that has reigned back technology.

In being nominated, Rod joins the company of influential science fiction authors such as William Gibson, Stephen Baxter and Richard Morgan.

Rod studied Mining Geology in the Department of Geology from 1980, graduating in 1983. He then worked in the Department of Physics for two years from 1986, managing a computer system for the ionospheric physics research group, returning on a few occasions since to give one-off classes on creative writing.

  • Read a feature and interview with Rod Duncan
  • Interview with Rod Duncan in the Leicester Mercury
  • The Bullet Catcher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Daughter is published by Angry Robot Books and available online from high street book stores and can be ordered through the University Bookshop.
]]> No publisher pt91 Geology Alumni Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Physics 2015-02-23T12:50:58Z Blog Entry \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2.9 million project provides platform for PhD students to pursue innovative research https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/november/20ac2-9-million-project-provides-platform-for-phd-students-to-pursue-innovative-research Launch of INTREPID Forensics at annual Forensic Sciences Conference The Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences held its annual conference at College Court, the University's conference centre and hotel, on 7-8 November and during the event officially launched the Interdisciplinary Training and Research Programme for Innovative Doctorates in Forensic Science (INTREPID Forensics).

INTREPID Forensics is a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2.9 million multidisciplinary project funded by the People Programme of the European Union\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Seventh Framework Programme and provides funding for 10 early stage researchers to pursue innovative research degrees focussing on areas applicable to the forensic sciences.

The project received nearly 300 applications from 58 different countries. The researchers will investigate forensic technologies with the potential to impact crime across Europe and globally.

The research projects are all based at the University of Leicester and are co-supervised by academics in a wide range of disciplines including Genetics, Criminology, Chemistry, Psychology, Engineering, Mathematics, Physics, Pathology and Immunity, Infection and Inflammation.

Dr Lisa Smith, INTREPID Forensics Project Coordinator and senior lecturer in the Department of Criminology, said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences conference and postgraduate symposium was the perfect event for the launch of the INTREPID Forensics project. It provided a great opportunity for the ten PhD researchers on the INTREPID project to network with other postgraduate students and industry experts, as well as raising awareness of the project within the wider forensic community.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Dr Anya Hunt, CEO of the Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences, added: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences were delighted to host their annual Autumn conference and AGM at College Court in Leicester this year. In the 30th anniversary year since the DNA profiling discovery at the University of Leicester, and with the launch if the INTREPID Forensics project, it was an opportunity not to be missed. The Society\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds trace evidence conference and parallel post graduate research symposium, organised in conjunction with Dr. Lisa Smith, were both a huge success. We look forward to seeing the INTREPID project develop and we hope to see the student present their findings at future events.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The conference, held at College Court, focused on the theme of trace evidence and attracted academics and practitioners from across the forensic sciences. There was also a Postgraduate Symposium which featured student research presentations from universities all over the UK and across a wide range of forensic disciplines.\ufffd\ufffd

All of the INTREPID Forensics researchers are writing research blogs about their experiences over the next three years. People can subscribe to the blogs by visiting the project website.

]]> No publisher ap507 Chemistry Psychology Genetics pathology Engineering Criminology Infection, Immunity and Inflammation Physics Mathematics 2014-11-18T11:40:00Z Blog Entry Exploring the origin of our Solar System through interstellar dust grains https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/august/exploring-the-mysteries-of-our-solar-system-through-its-interstellar-dust-grains Dr John Bridges involved in study observing first returned samples of space dust from another solar system An international team of scientists, including Dr John Bridges (pictured)\ufffd\ufffdfrom the Department of Physics and Astronomy, working with citizen scientists has examined dust grains gathered by the NASA Stardust spacecraft and brought back to Earth \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and has discovered that they originated in the interstellar dust stream.

Analysis of these\ufffd\ufffddust\ufffd\ufffdparticles, which are less than 1 millionth of a metre across,\ufffd\ufffdis significant for increasing our understanding of what interstellar grains are made of, in order to better understand the complexities of the Solar System\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds formation. As interstellar matter is the substance that generates new stars and planetary systems, particles such as those discovered could serve as building blocks for future planets.

The findings of the study have been\ufffd\ufffddocumented in an academic paper entitled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdEvidence for interstellar origin of seven dust particles collected by the Stardust spacecraft\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, published in the journal Science.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Physics Physics and Astronomy 2014-08-18T09:34:09Z Blog Entry Superman: Man of Steel and... super-powered solar panel? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/july/superman-man-of-steel-and-super-powered-solar-panel Physics students point out flaws in the science of Superman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds solar powered hijinks Superman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds powers are pretty well documented: flight; heat vision; an uncanny ability to pull off highly-questionable underwear arrangements. But who knew he was also the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds most powerful solar panel?

Four of our MPhys physics students have worked out Superman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds solar powered credentials in a paper for this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Special Physics Topics \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds safe to say he puts all earthly photovoltaic appliances to shame.

The students - Magdalena Szczykulska, Jason Watson, Lilian Garratt-Smithson and Alistair William Muir \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd had noted that the explanation given for Superman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds abilities in the DC comics was that he gets his energy from the electromagnetic radiation contained in the light from our sun.

They decided to put this explanation to the test, and applied the formula used to gauge the efficiency of regular solar panels \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd i.e the amount of energy they give out relative to how much energy from sunlight they have received.

After taking rough estimates of the area of Superman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds profile and the amount of energy he would need for a day\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds flight, they found his solar cell efficiency was a staggering 656,000 per cent.

This is a far sight better than the 44.7 per cent recorded for the most efficient solar panels. It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds also, frankly, impossible: he must be getting energy from somewhere else as well, according to the students.

So if you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre reading, Superman: it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds all very well protecting us from Lex Luthor - but if you really want to save the planet, you might want to share your secrets and put an end to the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds energy crisis.

The Journal of Physics Special Topics is a peer-reviewed student journal run by our Department of Physics and Astronomy.

Dr Klaas Wiersema
The study, published in the prestigious scientific journal Nature, uses evidence from observation of a GRB to rule out most of the existing theoretical predictions concerning the afterglow of the explosions.

For Dr Klaas Wiersema said the findings will change theoretical understandings of the afterglows of GRBs.\ufffd\ufffd The team from Leicester also included Dr Rhaana Starling, Professor Nial Tanvir, Professor Paul O\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdBrien and Professor Richard Willingale from the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Research Physics and Astronomy Physics Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student 2014-05-01T09:20:00Z Blog Entry Students debunk the myth that Icarus 'soared too high' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/april/students-debunk-the-myth-that-icarus-soared-too-high Centre for Interdisciplinary Science students publish paper on the science behind the mythological character's waxen wings The popular story of Icarus from Greek mythology suggests that he soared too close to the Sun while flying with waxen wings which melted under the intense heat - causing Icarus to plunge to his death. This story has since permeated Western culture as an allegory\ufffd\ufffdwarning against\ufffd\ufffdover-ambition.

Students Jonathan Cogle, Jake Cox, and Jimmy Pierce from The Centre for Interdisciplinary Science have published a new paper looking into the Icarusian myth,\ufffd\ufffdspecifically at the likelihood that the wax in\ufffd\ufffdhis wings would have melted during his flight - and have found\ufffd\ufffdthat it would have taken between about 43 and 70 minutes for the wax to melt, and the distance from the Sun would have played no part in the process.

The findings suggest that as long as Icarus\ufffd\ufffdstayed within breathable atmosphere and didn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt fly into any significant weather systems, the amount of sun hitting the wings would be almost constant. In the grand scheme of things, changing the distance between Icarus and the Sun\ufffd\ufffdwould make\ufffd\ufffdno difference - flying 10 meters off the ground or 10,000 would have little effect on the speed in which his wings would melt.

In fact, the paper suggests that, if anything, Icarus should have considered flying higher -\ufffd\ufffdin the first 10 kilometers above the Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds surface, the temperature can decrease from 20 degrees to -60 degrees Celsius. The higher you go, the colder it gets. Therefore, not only could Icarus fly as close to the Sun as he wanted, but he could have flown \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtoo close\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in order to prolong his flight.

Perhaps this suggests the old axiom that over-ambition can lead to your downfall should be revised - and that people should instead be encouraged to dream big and aim high.

]]> No publisher ap507 Physics and Astronomy Interdisciplinary science Magazine:Student Physics Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research 2014-04-24T10:55:00Z Blog Entry Camera obscurer: How the Doppler Effect could get you out of a speeding ticket https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/march/camera-obscurer-how-the-doppler-effect-could-get-you-out-of-a-speeding-ticket Physics and Astronomy students find it would be possible to become invisible to speed cameras \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd if you could travel at a sixth of the speed of light Our physics students are a cunning bunch. In a paper for this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Physics Special Topics, a group of four MPhys students from the Department of Physics and Astronomy\ufffd\ufffdworked out how you could avoid getting a speeding ticket - by driving so fast your car would become invisible to speed cameras.

It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds all down to the Doppler Effect \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the physical phenomenon which allows light from an object to be \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdshifted\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd upwards or downwards along the spectrum as the object moves to or from an observer.

According to the well-trodden formula astronomers use for working out the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdred shift\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of stars, you could theoretically drive fast enough for your number plate to be shifted out of the visible spectrum, rendering it undetectable to even the most beady-eyed of yellow boxes.

But the paper\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds authors - students Dan Worthy, Robert Garner, Jenny Gregory and Jessica Taylor-Ashley - are certainly not recommending you try out this dangerous and highly-illegal tactic for yourself.

Besides, it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds going to be a little while before we\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdve developed anything that could reach the necessary speeds. According to their calculations, you would have to be going at 119 million miles per hour to shift the yellow light of the number plate from its usual frequency at 515 terahertz to its required value at less than 400 terahertz, the boundary of visible light.

That\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a sixth of the speed of light \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd almost 800 times faster than the quickest man-made vehicle of all time, the Helios Probe.

In other words, it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds still best to stick to the speed limit - for all concerned.

The Journal of Physics Special Topics is a peer-reviewed student journal run by our Department of Physics and Astronomy.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Physics Magazine:Research Magazine:Student 2014-03-21T10:53:52Z Blog Entry A need for speed will drive you up the wall https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/march/A%20need%20for%20speed%20will%20drive%20you%20up%20the%20wall Driving a racing car at an angle of 90 degrees to the ground could be possible with the right track design, suggests student paper A group of four MPhys physics students from the Department of Physics and Astronomy have worked out that a racing car travelling at over 150 miles per hour would be able to stick to the walls of a completely circular speedway track with 90 degree banks - but don't\ufffd\ufffdbe tempted to give it a try next time you are stuck in traffic.

At speeds of 150mph, the force of gravity acting on a racing car would be less than the frictional force holding the car on the wall, meaning the car would easily be able to stay on the vertical banking.

The students published their findings in a final year paper for the Journal of Physics Special Topics, a peer-reviewed student journal run by the Department.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Physics Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff 2014-03-12T12:10:00Z Blog Entry Experts develop world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds first integrated night mapping system https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/february/experts-develop-world2019s-first-integrated-night-mapping-system Partnership with Bluesky to initiate night time aerial photo mapping trials The University in partnership with aerial survey specialist\ufffd\ufffdBluesky is to conduct trials of the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds first integrated night mapping system.

The resulting map accurate images will be a useful tool for managing street lighting operations and maintenance and as a resource to tackle energy inefficiency. Using advanced spatial queries and mapping techniques the Bluesky Night Mapper data can be used by Local Authorities and conservation organisations to provide an assessment of light pollution.

The night time images can also be used as an aid for street lighting inventories and condition assessments; with 7.4million road lights in the UK, identifying those requiring replacement could lead to substantial savings.

Additional applications of the night-time survey images are also expected to include measurement of illumination for energy consumption evaluations and additional intelligence to support innovative projects to \ufffd\ufffd\ufffddim\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd or even switch off selected streetlights in an effort to save money and reduce carbon emissions.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Magazine:Business Magazine:Research Physics and Astronomy Physics 2014-02-06T12:25:00Z Blog Entry Leicester luminaries shine https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/january/leicester-luminaries-win-astronomical-awards Stellar members from the same department win medals from the Royal Astronomical Society Three medals are to be presented to scientists from the Department of Physics and Astronomy for their outstanding achievements in the fields of astronomy and related sciences.\ufffd\ufffd It is a rare distinction for triple awards to be made to academics who all work in the same department.

The Royal Astronomical Society announced the following 2014 Awards to Professors at the University:

RAS Service Award to Professor Mark Lester, Head of the Department of Physics and Astronomy

Awarded to individuals who, through outstanding or exceptional work, have promoted, facilitated or encouraged the science of astronomy and developed their role in the life of the nation but whose achievement does not fall within the criteria of the Society's other awards.

RAS 'A' Jackson-Gwilt Medal to Professor George Fraser, Director of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Space Research Centre

Awarded for single investigations of outstanding merit in Invention, improvement, or development of astronomical instrumentation or techniques or for achievement in observational astronomy

RAS 'A' Eddington Medal to Professor Andrew King, Professor of Astrophysics

Awarded for single investigations of outstanding merit in theoretical astrophysics.


Congratulating the academics on their distinction, Vice-Chancellor Professor Sir Robert Burgess, said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdI am absolutely delighted that these three Leicester academics have been honoured by the Royal Astronomical Society, all of whom have given outstanding service to the University as well as to their discipline.\ufffd\ufffd The awards are richly deserved and indicate the success that has been achieved and the strength that Leicester has in the field of Physics and Astronomy.\ufffd\ufffd This will not only be really positive for the staff concerned but also for the Department and the wider University.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The Royal Astronomical Society (RAS), founded in 1820, encourages and promotes the study of astronomy, solar-system science, geophysics and closely related branches of science.

]]> No publisher ac555 Space Research Centre Space Magazine:Student Physics Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy 2013-12-20T09:20:00Z Blog Entry Gaia ready for take-off! https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/december/gaia-ready-for-take-off Europe\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds billion-star surveyor - worked on by University researchers - is ready for launch Gaia, Europe\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds billion-star surveyor worked on by researchers from the University and partners, is due to be launched into space on\ufffd\ufffdThursday\ufffd\ufffd19 December 2013, where it will embark on its mission to create a highly accurate 3D map of our galaxy.

By repeatedly observing a billion stars, with its billion-pixel video camera, the Gaia mission will allow astronomers to determine the origin and evolution of our galaxy.

Other tests\ufffd\ufffdwill be into gravity, mapping our inner solar system and uncovering tens of thousands of previously unseen objects, including asteroids, planets and supernovae.

The first Gaia recordings will be of discoveries of new sources \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd supernovae, extreme variable stars and blazars - which will be discovered at the Cambridge processing centre, and immediately made available for study by both professionals and the interested public.
